Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Operational Reconfigurability of Constrained Moving-Boundary Processes through Agile Motion Planning with Application to Steel Continuous Casting

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research effort supported by this award is aimed at providing operational flexibility of controlled systems with moving boundaries, such as those involving melting and/or solidification, to meet changing production demands. The objective, referred to as motion planning, is a timely generation of commands to the closed loop, the latter being composed of a process coupled to a model-based feedback control law, to guarantee process motions that provide optimal product quality. Focusing on continuous steel casting, the research approach is to start from the improvement of process model and clear delineation of static and dynamic constraints on its behavior and progress to creation of motion planning algorithms that satisfy the constraints. Deliverables include fundamental control-theoretic results, fast optimal motion planning tools for moving boundary systems, software/hardware demonstration and validation on an industrial caster at Nucor Steel, documentation of research results in publications, and engineering student education.

If successful, the results of this research will offer widely applicable motion planning tools that rigorously optimize operation of moving boundary processes, providing significant economic and environmental impacts. Example applications include crystal growth, solid and liquid burning, and multiple forms of melting and solidification. For example, a one percent reduction in yield loss in continuous steel casting would save about $150 million per year, while optimizing cooling conditions to conserve just 10% more of the cast steel internal energy would produce $350 million per year savings during reheating. Student researchers will master and broadly disseminate expertise and commercialize the results. The research and educational infrastructure will be significantly enhanced through student involvement, international collaboration, and broad dissemination of knowledge.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award enabled making the following major contributions:

1) Fundamental advancement of the spray cooling monitoring and control system for continuous steel casting. The system includes four sub-programs

i) a software sensor (state estimator) that estimates two-dimensional temperature profiles and liquid pool shape in real time,

ii) a controller that manipulates water flow rate in each spray zone to maintain stable tracking of surface temperature setpoints, based on feedback from the software sensor,

iii) a real-time displayer of the shell profile, temperature distribution, spray flow rates, and setpoints on both the inner and the outer radii surfaces of the solidifying shell, forming a human-machine interface supervisory loop, and

iv) a setpoint-generator/motion-planner of temperature profiles - the optimal motion-planning algorithm and/or data-base command generator supervised by a plant metallurgist.

The system described above solves 200 one-dimensional equations calculating spatially distributed temperature and other variables every second and assembles them into a two-dimensional approximation of the solidifying shell dynamics. The full three-dimensional transient temperature distribution through the entire solidifying shell is obtained by assembling several two-dimensional cross-sections.

Throughout the present award, the systems has been fundamentally advanced through accomplishing the following tasks.

a) Experimental validation of the real-time shell temperature and thickness software estimator.

b) Inclusion of the effect of formation of the insulating steam layer between the cooling water droplets and the hot steel surface (so-called Leidenfrost effect).

c) Inclusion of the real-time steel shell stress and strain estimate for prediction and minimization of cracks.

d) Successful closed-loop testing of the estimator/controller in production, permitting the high-quality/high-throughput process automation.

e) Rigorous real-time process estimate convergence proof during the online recalibration, when the latter has access only to sparse discrete-in-time temperature measurements.

f) Derivation and software implementation of the novel optimal motion planning algorithms for fastest maintenance of the solidifying shell profile under the fault-induced sharp changes in the casting speed.

g) Derivation of the spray cooling motion planning algorithm for minimizing the reheat energy expenditure during rolling of the hot continuously cast steel.

The methodology proposed has been implemented at Arcelor/Mittal, the world's largest steel producer and at Nucor Steel, the largest US steel producer, significantly enhancing productivity and quality of the cast steel.

2) Fundamental theoretical and computational support of mold oscillator resonance modeling, simulation, and control in continuous steel casters. A four-beam caster mold oscillator assembly at the Nucor Steel Decatur Alabama plant experienced violent shaking at 3.4 Hz, precluding implementation of smaller oscillation magnitude, which reduces the steel shell cracks, but requires operation at higher frequencies. The problem solution was obtained though carrying out the following tasks.

a) It was found through plant measurements that the actuator nonlinearity generates the sinusoids at the beam assembly input, and that these sinusoids excite the beam resonance.

b) A high fidelity nonlinear oscillator model was developed to explore the system dynamic features and test proposed control approaches.

c) A control solution was found and implemented in collaboration with plant personnel.

d) A rigorous control theory for mold oscillator resonance suppression was developed.

e) A technique to tune the model to a mold oscillator for any caster was completed to permit application of the industry-proven solution to other casters.

f) The value for Nucor Steel Decatur of the completed mold oscillator control project was assessed by plant metallurgist Madeline Rembold as follows:  "The success of the oscillator project - providing resonance-free frequency increase from 3.5 Hz to over 5 Hz at a smaller oscillation magnitude (shorter stroke) - was essential to Nucor's current status as one of the US leading steel manufacturers.  Since the implementation of a shorter stroke, we have decreased transverse cracking by 50% across all products.   Another advantage has been the ability to add cooling water for quicker solidification. This has allowed us to increase the casting speeds on crack-sensitive and high-strength/low-alloy (HSLA) grades, and consistently run at 6 cm per second or higher, a level previously unattainable. The speed increase has also launched an equipment upgrade cycle, which is paving the way for running even faster in the near future."

g) Transition to academia was carried out - the mold oscillator project formed the basis for the PI's book on instrumentation, signal processing, and control  - an undergraduate text showing how these three areas come together to solve difficult mechanical design problems.

3) Bulging

Model of the solidifying steel shell bulging was developed to localize the bulging onset at a particular spray zone. Motion planning for bulging prevention has been initiated.

 

Students advancement. Four PhD students graduated under support from the present award.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The award enabled making the following major contributions: 1) Fundamental advancement of the spray cooling monitoring and control system for continuous steel casting. The system includes four sub-programs i) a software sensor (state estimator) that estimates two-dimensional temperature profiles and liquid pool shape in real time, ii) a controller that manipulates water flow rate in each spray zone to maintain stable tracking of surface temperature setpoints, based on feedback from the software sensor, iii) a real-time displayer of the shell profile, temperature distribution, spray flow rates, and setpoints on both the inner and the outer radii surfaces of the solidifying shell, forming a human-machine interface supervisory loop, and iv) a setpoint-generator/motion-planner of temperature profiles - the optimal motion-planning algorithm and/or data-base command generator supervised by a plant metallurgist. The system described above solves 200 one-dimensional equations calculating spatially distributed temperature and other variables every second and assembles them into a two-dimensional approximation of the solidifying shell dynamics. The full three-dimensional transient temperature distribution through the entire solidifying shell is obtained by assembling several two-dimensional cross-sections. Throughout the present award, the systems has been fundamentally advanced through accomplishing the following tasks. a) Experimental validation of the real-time shell temperature and thickness software estimator. b) Inclusion of the effect of formation of the insulating steam layer between the cooling water droplets and the hot steel surface (so-called Leidenfrost effect). c) Inclusion of the real-time steel shell stress and strain estimate for prediction and minimization of cracks. d) Successful closed-loop testing of the estimator/controller in production, permitting the high-quality/high-throughput process automation. e) Rigorous real-time process estimate convergence proof during the online recalibration, when the latter has access only to sparse discrete-in-time temperature measurements. f) Derivation and software implementation of the novel optimal motion planning algorithms for fastest maintenance of the solidifying shell profile under the fault-induced sharp changes in the casting speed. g) Derivation of the spray cooling motion planning algorithm for minimizing the reheat energy expenditure during rolling of the hot continuously cast steel. The methodology proposed has been implemented at Arcelor/Mittal, the world's largest steel producer and at Nucor Steel, the largest US steel producer, significantly enhancing productivity and quality of the cast steel. 2) Fundamental theoretical and computational support of mold oscillator resonance modeling, simulation, and control in continuous steel casters. A four-beam caster mold oscillator assembly at the Nucor Steel Decatur Alabama plant experienced violent shaking at 3.4 Hz, precluding implementation of smaller oscillation magnitude, which reduces the steel shell cracks, but requires operation at higher frequencies. The problem solution was obtained though carrying out the following tasks. a) It was found through plant measurements that the actuator nonlinearity generates the sinusoids at the beam assembly input, and that these sinusoids excite the beam resonance. b) A high fidelity nonlinear oscillator model was developed to explore the system dynamic features and test proposed control approaches. c) A control solution was found and implemented in collaboration with plant personnel. d) A rigorous control theory for mold oscillator resonance suppression was developed. e) A technique to tune the model to a mold oscillator for any caster was completed to permit application of the industry-proven solution to other casters. f) The value for Nucor Steel Decatur of the completed mold oscillator control project was assessed by plant metallurgist Madeline Rembold as follows: "The success of the oscillator project - providing resonance-free frequency increase from 3.5 Hz to over 5 Hz at a smaller oscillation magnitude (shorter stroke) - was essential to Nucor's current status as one of the US leading steel manufacturers. Since the implementation of a shorter stroke, we have decreased transverse cracking by 50% across all products. Another advantage has been the ability to add cooling water for quicker solidification. This has allowed us to increase the casting speeds on crack-sensitive and high-strength/low-alloy (HSLA) grades, and consistently run at 6 cm per second or higher, a level previously unattainable. The speed increase has also launched an equipment upgrade cycle, which is paving the way for running even faster in the near future." g) Transition to academia was carried out - the mold oscillator project formed the basis for the PI's book on instrumentation, signal processing, and control - an undergraduate text showing how these three areas come together to solve difficult mechanical design problems. 3) Bulging Model of the solidifying steel shell bulging was developed to localize the bulging onset at a particular spray zone. Motion planning for bulging prevention has been initiated. Students advancement. Four PhD students graduated under support from the present award.
